byline.original: By HOWARD BECK and KEN BELSON

abstract: NBA's 30 team owners, locked in labor negotiations, are bound by mutual interests and common dependencies that outweigh competitive impulses as they continue to seek big givebacks from the players, even at the cost of canceling games.
snippet: Bound by mutual interests, like reducing expenses, and a mutual dependence, the owners of the N.B.A.’s 30 teams have different views of how to achieve their goals.
lead_paragraph: Bound by mutual interests, like reducing expenses, and a mutual dependence, the owners of the N.B.A.’s 30 teams have different views of how to achieve their goals.

headline.main: N.B.A. Owners’ Mutual Dependence Outweighs Divisions
headline.print_headline: N.B.A. Owners’ Mutual Dependence Outweighs Divisions
headline.seo: N.B.A. Are Not Unified in All Their Interests
